taxonConcepts.nameAccordingTo: Species 2000 & ITIS Catalogue of Life: April 2013

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: occurs (regularly, as a native taxon) in multiple nations

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: South America:  Orinoco River basin, in the upper Orinoco River drainage in Colombia and Venezuela; Amazon River basin, in the upper Negro River basin.
dataObjects.references: Kullander, S.O. 2003 Cichlidae (Cichlids). p. 605-654. In R.E. Reis, S.O. Kullander and C.J. Ferraris, Jr. (eds.) Checklist of the Freshwater Fishes of South and Central America. Porto Alegre: EDIPUCRS, Brasil. (Ref. 36377)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Orinoco River basin and Amazon River basin: Brazil, Colombia and Venezuela; established in Florida, U.S.A.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Size
dataObjects.title: Max. size
dataObjects.description: 20.0 cm SL (male/unsexed; (Ref. 6466))
dataObjects.references: Lee, D.S., C.R. Gilbert, C.H. Hocutt, R.E. Jenkins, D.E. McAllister and J.R. Stauffer 1980 Atlas of North American freshwater fishes. North Carolina State Museum of Natural History. 867 p. (Ref. 6466)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObjects.title: Environment
dataObjects.description: benthopelagic; freshwater; brackish; pH range: 5.0 - 6.5; dH range: 0 - 6

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Diseases
dataObjects.description: White spot Disease. Parasitic infestations (protozoa, worms, etc.)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Diseases
dataObjects.description: Hole-in-the-Head Disease. Parasitic infestations (protozoa, worms, etc.)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Diseases
dataObjects.description: Bacterial Infections (general). Bacterial diseases

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeCycle
dataObjects.description: Up to 200 eggs are deposited on stones or roots and defended by both parents: larvae are taken into the mouth. Parental care can last up to 6 weeks (Ref. 40602).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Threats
dataObjects.description: Not Evaluated
